subject: Support configure -platform linux-clang-libc++

values.-1: I would prefer this is not merged as is
values.+1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

messages.message: Patch Set 2: Commit message was updated.

Patch Set 2:

So what should I change?

Patch Set 2:

> Patch Set 2:
> 
> So what should I change?

I was about to propose something, but .... Isn't the flag somebody to be replaced for user projects as well?

In that case regardless of whether we make it a feature or just keep the current code as-is, it won't be applied to user projects.

This would need more work. Perhaps by doing the search and replace in the qt provided toolchain file itself. And none of the current functions are available there.

Patch Set 2:

> Patch Set 2:
> 
> > Patch Set 2:
> > 
> > So what should I change?
> 
> I was about to propose something, but .... Isn't the flag somebody to be replaced for user projects as well?
> 
> In that case regardless of whether we make it a feature or just keep the current code as-is, it won't be applied to user projects.
> 
> This would need more work. Perhaps by doing the search and replace in the qt provided toolchain file itself. And none of the current functions are available there.

Right, I was just concerned about building Qt, since this old configure flags is only for Qt anyway.

Patch Set 2:

> Right, I was just concerned about building Qt, since this old configure flags is only for Qt anyway.

Not sure I follow.

Doesn't passing linux-clang-libc++ to qt's 5.15 configure ensure that --std=libc++ is passed on to qmake examples as well?

Patch Set 2:

> Patch Set 2:
> 
> > Right, I was just concerned about building Qt, since this old configure flags is only for Qt anyway.
> 
> Not sure I follow.
> 
> Doesn't passing linux-clang-libc++ to qt's 5.15 configure ensure that --std=libc++ is passed on to qmake examples as well?

Sure, this should pass it on to examples too. I guess it should also work with qmake end-user applications, but that is assuming it already passes that on, but then currently gets the stdlibs mixed up.

Do you mean if you make examples external projects? That might require something extra.

Patch Set 2:

I think if you currently specify -platform linux-clang-libc++ to Qt6's configure, that already takes care of building examples with qmake with the proper --stdlib=libc++ flag.

Because -platform linux-clang-libc++ gets transformed to QT_QMAKE_TARGET_MKSPEC, and we then record that in qmake's qt.conf file as TargetSpec.

And with the current change implementation, you would get the --stdlib=lib++ flag added when building Qt itself.

But building examples with CMake would still use --stdlib=libstdc++ which means we'd mixing Qt's libc++ usage with the example's libstdc++.

And to solve that, i think we'd need to do it in the qt generated cmake toolchain file.

Patch Set 2:

After investigating this a bit, it looks like upstream CMake doesn't explicitly add neither --stdlib=libc++ nor --stdlib=libstdc++ except for android, which is done here https://github.com/Kitware/CMake/blob/master/Modules/Platform/Android-Common.cmake#L55 and 2 more times on line 67 and 74.

This tells me that for the particular case of Desktop linux-clang-libc++ mkspec, we don't actually need to remove / replace flags, only add.

So instead of doing the dance in QtFlagHandlingHelpers.cmake, we can instead add a new feature to qtbase/configure.cmake, called 'stdlib_libcpp'.

QtProcessConfigureArgs can detect the exact 'linux-clang-libc++' mkspec, and pass -DINPUT_stdlib_libcpp=ON when configuring qtbase.

And QtPlatformTargetHelpers.cmake can just call target_link_options/target_compile_options with --stdlib=libc++ if the feature is enabled. That will propagate to the Qt build and standalone CMake examples.

The new feature should have 

 CONDITION LINUX AND NOT ANDROID 
 AUTODETECT OFF

Patch Set 3:

This does cause some misdetection of c++17 features, since the compile test doesn't use the same stdlib argument. 

In particular cxx17_bm_searcher is missing from libc++ (it is just not complete in C++17 as stdlibc++)

subject: Properly propagate hover events to all parent mouse areas

values.-1: I would prefer this is not merged as is

messages.message:
Patch Set 1:

My first attempt to upload a patch to Qt and my first experience with gerrit.
I apologize in advance if I do something wrong at first time.
And my English is not ideal, so sorry for that as well. 😊
Patch Set 2: Commit message was updated.

Patch Set 2:

Hi, any thought? Should I keep working on it, e.g. deduplicate this code?

Patch Set 2:

Pre Continuous Integration Quick Check: Running

Details: https://testresults.qt.io/coin/integration/qt/qtdeclarative/tasks/1639421694

Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

Pre Continuous Integration Quick Check: Passed

Patch looks good. Thanks.

Details: https://testresults.qt.io/coin/integration/qt/qtdeclarative/tasks/1639421694

Patch Set 2:

We need better test coverage then, and we need to use the new autotest to prove that it's really the same behavior as 5.15; because I've been a bit confused about when that changed.  I'm pretty sure it propagated only to direct-parent MouseAreas, a longer time ago.  And there is a pretty good chance someone else will write the opposite bug: they liked 6.2 as it was, and then it changed.  Then maybe we'd have to add another property to MouseArea to control it.

Implementation-wise, now you do this in MouseArea instead of in the hover delivery logic, so the change is confined to MouseArea, which means behavior will probably be inconsistent with the way Controls does it, right?  So is it correct to say that with Controls, this behavior is not desired, i.e. you don't need to hover a Button and its parent at the same time?

The main use case I always think of is the drawer that flies out when you hover its edge, with buttons and other controls on it.  I wanted to make sure HoverHandler would work well for that.  (In fullscreen desktop applications that's an excellent application of Fitts' Law, whereas on a touchscreen, the current behavior of Drawer, to require swiping to open it, makes more sense.)  So the Button and the Drawer have to be hovered at the same time.  But in practice Drawer { HoverHandler { } } doesn't work too well (it can detect hover only when the drawer is already open) so we're talking about custom components for now.  I'm not even sure how many Controls are actually designed to detect hover on their own, except for Button; but if there are any that are nestable, then maybe we'd want hover delivery to be consistent between those and MouseArea.

And you mention the item view delegate with controls that appear when you hover; I've done that before too.  (It's inefficient though if each cell needs its own instances of the controls, and yet you only ever hover one cell at a time.  We should come up with a better pattern for that.)

Patch Set 2:

> Patch Set 2:
> 
> We need better test coverage then, and we need to use the new autotest to prove that it's really the same behavior as 5.15; because I've been a bit confused about when that changed.  I'm pretty sure it propagated only to direct-parent MouseAreas, a longer time ago.  And there is a pretty good chance someone else will write the opposite bug: they liked 6.2 as it was, and then it changed.  Then maybe we'd have to add another property to MouseArea to control it.
> 
> Implementation-wise, now you do this in MouseArea instead of in the hover delivery logic, so the change is confined to MouseArea, which means behavior will probably be inconsistent with the way Controls does it, right?  So is it correct to say that with Controls, this behavior is not desired, i.e. you don't need to hover a Button and its parent at the same time?
> 
> The main use case I always think of is the drawer that flies out when you hover its edge, with buttons and other controls on it.  I wanted to make sure HoverHandler would work well for that.  (In fullscreen desktop applications that's an excellent application of Fitts' Law, whereas on a touchscreen, the current behavior of Drawer, to require swiping to open it, makes more sense.)  So the Button and the Drawer have to be hovered at the same time.  But in practice Drawer { HoverHandler { } } doesn't work too well (it can detect hover only when the drawer is already open) so we're talking about custom components for now.  I'm not even sure how many Controls are actually designed to detect hover on their own, except for Button; but if there are any that are nestable, then maybe we'd want hover delivery to be consistent between those and MouseArea.
> 
> And you mention the item view delegate with controls that appear when you hover; I've done that before too.  (It's inefficient though if each cell needs its own instances of the controls, and yet you only ever hover one cell at a time.  We should come up with a better pattern for that.)

Thank you for such detailed answer. Please check my comment inside the bug.
This behavior has definitelly changed since Qt 5.15.2 and I'm just trying to get it back to make the migration process as easy as possible for Qt 5 users. So that they don't run into the same issues I faced when did it.

Patch Set 2:

>

> > 
> > We need better test coverage then, and we need to use the new autotest to prove that it's really the same behavior as 5.15; because I've been a bit confused about when that changed.  I'm pretty sure it propagated only to direct-parent MouseAreas, a longer time ago.  And there is a pretty good chance someone else will write the opposite bug: they liked 6.2 as it was, and then it changed.  Then maybe we'd have to add another property to MouseArea to control it.
> > 
> > Implementation-wise, now you do this in MouseArea instead of in the hover delivery logic, so the change is confined to MouseArea, which means behavior will probably be inconsistent with the way Controls does it, right?  So is it correct to say that with Controls, this behavior is not desired, i.e. you don't need to hover a Button and its parent at the same time?
> > 
> > The main use case I always think of is the drawer that flies out when you hover its edge, with buttons and other controls on it.  I wanted to make sure HoverHandler would work well for that.  (In fullscreen desktop applications that's an excellent application of Fitts' Law, whereas on a touchscreen, the current behavior of Drawer, to require swiping to open it, makes more sense.)  So the Button and the Drawer have to be hovered at the same time.  But in practice Drawer { HoverHandler { } } doesn't work too well (it can detect hover only when the drawer is already open) so we're talking about custom components for now.  I'm not even sure how many Controls are actually designed to detect hover on their own, except for Button; but if there are any that are nestable, then maybe we'd want hover delivery to be consistent between those and MouseArea.
> > 
> > And you mention the item view delegate with controls that appear when you hover; I've done that before too.  (It's inefficient though if each cell needs its own instances of the controls, and yet you only ever hover one cell at a time.  We should come up with a better pattern for that.)
> 
> Thank you for such detailed answer. Please check my comment inside the bug.
> This behavior has definitelly changed since Qt 5.15.2 and I'm just trying to get it back to make the migration process as easy as possible for Qt 5 users. So that they don't run into the same issues I faced when did it.

Also I totaly agree that delegates should be kept as simple as possible in terms of performance, so instantiating something that is not usable/visible right now is not best practise. But this is how our designers see our UI. 😞 To somehow workaround such perfomance/memory overhead we're using Loaders where possible.

messages.message:
Patch Set 1:

What will it break?

Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> What will it break?

 Will break the unmarshaling of UiImport if the Qt version is >= 5.14, here: https://code.qt.io/cgit/qt-labs/vstools.git/tree/src/qtvstools/QML/Parser/QmlParserInterop.cs#n343

Patch Set 1:

Ok so QtVSTools also depends on the Qt version used to compile VsQml. As far as I know, C# does not accept BLA=514 defines, but only booleans. So QtVSTools could have QT514 and QT515 but that would be something the user has to do manually. Can someone think of a more automatic way?

Perhaps in the long run we should have a copy of the AST stuff from declarative which is updated regularly like Creator does as far as I know.

Patch Set 1:

I think we can put this one to rest 😊

subject: Support external editors for locator, projects and file system tree

values.-1: I would prefer this is not merged as is
values.+1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

values.-1: Sanity problems found
values.+1: Sanity review passed

messages.message:
Patch Set 1:

See the relation chain.

This makes it possible to e.g. set "Qt Designer" as the default editor for the application/x-designer mime type, and open the external Qt Designer when opening a .ui file via project tree, file system tree, and locator.

I'm not sure if it would make sense to enable that for e.g. search results or profiler items as well, as long as we don't have a way to configure external editors that can open files at a specific position.
Uploaded patch set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased.

Patch Set 2:

(3 comments)

After reading a bit I think it is a bit strange that the openEditor function returns a nullptr for a succesfull open operation for external editors. And I'm not sure where this is checked over the code base. What about using a standalone function instead a flag for this functionality? It seems it is currently never used in conjunction with other flags.

Patch Set 2:

> Patch Set 2:
> 
> (3 comments)
> 
> After reading a bit I think it is a bit strange that the openEditor function returns a nullptr for a succesfull open operation for external editors. And I'm not sure where this is checked over the code base. What about using a standalone function instead a flag for this functionality? It seems it is currently never used in conjunction with other flags.

The editor return value is potentially used in the ProjectTreeWidget::openItem case with AllowExternalEditor. Arguable this could use openEditorAt, but that also does the same.

We'd also need the additional variant for both openEditor and openEditorAt, and we'd still need to pass it as a "flag" to EditorManagerPrivate::openEditor (though it could be separate to the other OpenEditorFlags) to avoid repetition. I don't have a great idea for new function names either.

Since openEditor(At) can always return nullptr on failure, every caller that wants to use the return value needs to check it in any case, so there is no new requirement for that.

So all in all I think just having the additional flag for OpenEditorFlags is ok, even though not perfect.

Patch Set 2:

> So all in all I think just having the additional flag for OpenEditorFlags is ok, even though not perfect.

Okay.

subject: WIP: QObjectCompatPropery: Allow for different storage and interface types

values.-1: I would prefer this is not merged as is
values.+1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

values.-1: Sanity problems found
values.+1: Sanity review passed

messages.message:
Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2 Sanity-Review+1

Apparently pushing a Work In Progress

Patch Set 2: Sanity-Review-1

(4 comments)

Apparently pushing a Work In Progress

See http://wiki.qt.io/Early_Warning_System for explanations.

Patch Set 2:

This is currently a mixup of two ideas, which I'll separate properly later. Feedback on the design and notes on potential issues would be appreciated:
- We want to support a different storage type then what is exposed in the interface. In Qt5, you only had to ensure that your setter and getter converted the types accordingly. With Q*Property, you would also need to deal with QBindable. There, we have the extra complication that we cannot simply have a
QBindable<T> for a property of type S, as otherwise the information from the metatype system wouldn't match, causing e.g. issues in QML. However, the bindable would always the type that is actually stored in the type. With this change, it uses instead the "interface" type, as long as you provide an appropriate getter.
- In most custom setters, we already compare if the new value == old value. If we just return that information from the setter, we don't have to compare anything again in the bindingWrapper. That becomes especially relevant for the case where the type in the interface and storage don't match, as we cannot simply use valueBypassingBindings() anymore (operator==(StorageType, InterfaceType) might not actually exist).

Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Build and autotests succeeded.
- success: macOS Latest Clang (https://github.com/cristianadam/qt-creator/runs/4506989992?check_suite_focus=true)
- success: Ubuntu Latest GCC (https://github.com/cristianadam/qt-creator/runs/4506989927?check_suite_focus=true)
- success: Windows Latest MinGW (https://github.com/cristianadam/qt-creator/runs/4506989869?check_suite_focus=true)
- success: Windows Latest MSVC (https://github.com/cristianadam/qt-creator/runs/4506989807?check_suite_focus=true)

Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

> QmlDesigner: Enable component library context menu while searching
> 
> The only item visible in the menu is remove module, as hiding
> categories during search is not supported.

I don't really understand the relationship between the title and the description, nor the relationship between this commit message and the actual changes.

It seems that the context menu _items_ are made visible or hidden, not the menu itself. So I don't get how the menu is enabled when... searchActive is true => menu items are hidden.

I didn't find that said "Remove module" menu item. I only found a "Hide Category" menu item that is visible just as before.

Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

> Patch Set 2:
> 
> (1 comment)
> 
> > QmlDesigner: Enable component library context menu while searching
> > 
> > The only item visible in the menu is remove module, as hiding
> > categories during search is not supported.
> 
> I don't really understand the relationship between the title and the description, nor the relationship between this commit message and the actual changes.
> 
> It seems that the context menu _items_ are made visible or hidden, not the menu itself. So I don't get how the menu is enabled when... searchActive is true => menu items are hidden.
> 
> I didn't find that said "Remove module" menu item. I only found a "Hide Category" menu item that is visible just as before.

The context menu was not previously shown at all while search was active, so the title is correct in my opinion. The description is also accurate in my opinion.

The menu itself is shown by moduleContextMenu.popup() calls, some of which are now executed when search is active, which was not done previously. Menu item visibility states were changed because previously they didn't consider menu being visible at all during search.

"Remove module" item is available when you right click on the module name in component library. It is enabled when none of the items provided by it are in use.
Change has been successfully cherry-picked as fe1f5a644e8b0e95f73f8c6f6f56ad1af5aaf648 by Miikka Heikkinen

Details: https://testresults.qt.io/coin/integration/pyside/pyside-setup/tasks/1639382603

Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

Reading through the history, this was introduced since there were inconsistencies in the Qt Api 
(class QProcess had a signal error() and a method error()), which were changed in 6 (signal errorOccurred()).  In principle, we should have kicked out this special handling out for PYSide 6 entirely... not sure if we can do this in PySide 7...

Patch Set 3:

> Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1
> 
> Reading through the history, this was introduced since there were inconsistencies in the Qt Api 
> (class QProcess had a signal error() and a method error()), which were changed in 6 (signal errorOccurred()).  In principle, we should have kicked out this special handling out for PYSide 6 entirely... not sure if we can do this in PySide 7...

We can not now because PyQt6 supports it. 
The only reason for my effort.

messages.message:
Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I don't think this is a good idea for everyone. Make it dependent on the regular warnings-are-errors setting.

Also, don't enable it for user applications (meaning: no qmake change).

Patch Set 1:

> I don't think this is a good idea for everyone. Make it dependent on the regular warnings-are-errors setting.

OK.

> Also, don't enable it for user applications (meaning: no qmake change).

The qmake part will only affect Qt modules, user projects will not be affected

Patch Set 1:

There are no Qt modules using qmake.

Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> There are no Qt modules using qmake.

In principle, you can still build Qt modules with qmake.  That's completely untested by now and we should remove that ability.  I've created https://bugreports.qt.io/browse/QTBUG-98453 to track this.

Patch Set 2:

> Make it dependent on the regular warnings-are-errors setting.

Done.

> Also, don't enable it for user applications (meaning: no qmake change).

Done.
Patch Set 4: Commit message was updated.

Patch Set 4:

Have you checked, if all the Qt modules "compiler warning free" are also "linker warning free"? Because I think otherwise integrations of other modules will fail when this qtbase change lands in qt5.git

Patch Set 4:

> Have you checked, if all the Qt modules "compiler warning free" are also "linker warning free"? Because I think otherwise integrations of other modules will fail when this qtbase change lands in qt5.git

I only tested QtBase, but what you said is reasonable, I need to check all modules indeed. I will check this.

messages.message:
Patch Set 1:

I have just upgraded to monterey and couldn't reproduce this yet. Release build passed, debug build is in progress.

Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> I have just upgraded to monterey and couldn't reproduce this yet. Release build passed, debug build is in progress.

Note the bug is about 5.15 if that makes any difference

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

I can't reproduce this issue with 90 and 94-based. I can reproduce with 87-based (5.15) but replacing shrink_to_fit() with reserve() doesn't fix the issue. The error message is the same, it has problem with shrink_to_fit. If I remove this particular line, the build completes.

Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2
> 
> I can't reproduce this issue with 90 and 94-based. I can reproduce with 87-based (5.15) but replacing shrink_to_fit() with reserve() doesn't fix the issue. The error message is the same, it has problem with shrink_to_fit. If I remove this particular line, the build completes.

Where does it claim shrink_to_fit is used if you replace the line?

Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

works for me on monterey, I'm not sure if this breaks build on older macOS versions.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

Works on Big Sur as well.
Change has been successfully cherry-picked as 7ff159da128c4f249b468f3ff972f864d243c742 by Allan Sandfeld Jensen

Patch Set 3:

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> > Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2
> > 
> > I can't reproduce this issue with 90 and 94-based. I can reproduce with 87-based (5.15) but replacing shrink_to_fit() with reserve() doesn't fix the issue. The error message is the same, it has problem with shrink_to_fit. If I remove this particular line, the build completes.
> 
> Where does it claim shrink_to_fit is used if you replace the line?

I expect to still see shrink_to_fit in the undefined symbols error if shrink_to_fit() usage is replaced with reserve() rather than reserve(0), because libc++ in the macOS 12 SDK implements reserve() (not reserve(size_t)) simply as a call to shrink_to_fit(), and the output object for string16.cc only contained reserve(unsigned long) (i.e. reserve(size_t)), not reserve().
